@realmoney May 09, 2019 | 02:36 PM EDT DOUG KASS Managing My Index Hedge Today The S&P has now rallied by almost 40 handles from the day's lows. As gathered from my earlier commentary, I am not surprised. Nevertheless, breadth is still negative (1340 advancers/1580 decliners

on the NYSE). I have done a good job in managing my Index hedge today (and all week). After covering half of my shorts near the day's lows I am inclined to stick with my medium-sized (SPY) and QQQ shorts (reshorted at about these levels) - and wait to respond to tonight's news.

Or maybe NOT respond to tonight's news. For, as I mentioned in the Comments Section yesterday, it's not necessary to be "balls to the wall" 24/7. Sometimes, especially in a "newsy" market dominated by machines and algos, it's a good idea to take one's foot off the peddler even
regardless of one's conviction. I sort of feel that way now. @jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @TeamCavuto

On @realmoney @jimcramer May 09, 2019 | 11:22 AM EDT DOUG KASS I Covered Half of My Index Shorts Just Now * We are starting to build in the discount to no trade deal We are now down by almost 4% this week Apropos to my comments earlier I am again trying to "finesse" the markets

and I am taking in about half of my (SPY) (under $284) and (QQQ) ($182.70) shorts (from medium sized to small sized): My most likely outcome of the trade negotiations is that President Trump says some vaguely encouraging words (having little substance) and announces that

the discussions with China will continue for an unspecified amount of time. This will be a shallow attempt to "steady" the markets and could be greeted with a temporary but short-lived bounce as investors see through the difficulties in reaching a deal.

Of course the risk is that stocks tank from current prices (and I am left with small Index shorts) but I am willing to take the risk based on the expectation that I can reshort at higher prices. @tomkeene Trading opportunistically!

@realmoney May 09, 2019 | 09:04 AM EDT DOUG KASS Not the Art of the Deal * To this observer, the trade deal with China "smelled" from the beginning As mentioned in my frequent comments in my Diary over the last six months, I have strongly believed that the president's deal with

China was virtually "dead at birth." Despite suggestions otherwise - on Real Money Pro and elsewhere - it was never likely that tariff pressures were ever going to force China to succumb and altar deep rooted policy and the country's "evolution" and planned economic growth

strategies. As written previously, President Trump constructs hastily crafted policy (on the back of a napkin) and delivers through the timeframe of a tweet - while China thinks in terms of decades and even a century. The president characteristically believes that the power of

his personal relationships will serve as a successful catalyst to deal making around the world. Unfortunately, (many investors/traders and) he may now be learning that complex policy issues are far different than conducting a New York City real estate deal.

Trump's approach failed to comprehend the magnitude of the tough structural issues (that were never going to be resolved with China) and, instead, leaned on a focus of the bilateral trade deficit. Technology transfer, state sponsored industrial policy, cyber issues and

intellectual property theft were likely never on the table of serious negotiation from China's standpoint and despite Trump's protestations that discussions were going well. As I have suggested for months, the unilateral imposition of tariffs will cause more economic disruptiont.

than the Administration recognizes (in our flat and interconnected economic world): * China's role in world trade is important - the country is the third largest exporter in the world. * Specifically, China is a prime source of cheap, imported goods for American consumers.

* China is the largest owner of U.S. debt. Last night at a political rally in the Panhandle of Florida the president said that "we don't have to do business" with China. Trump's statement is short sighted and Friday's trade negotiations outcome is not likely to be a market
friendly development. @Morning_Joe @morningmoneyben @morningmika #msnbc #cnn @JoyAnnReid @AriMelber @TheBeatWithAri @SteveRattner @Sarge986 @realmoney @realdonaldtrump
Though strategies may differ (funnymental, technical, anticipatory, reactionary) - markets are not for sitting they are for doing. @realmoney

of a number of fundamental issues and risks? I am obvs doing the later but who knows? Maybe The Shadow! piped.video/watch?v=BUK7vo92… Discussed on @realmoney today....
